Cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides catalyzed by dicationic ionic liquids mediated metal halide: Influence of the dication on catalytic activity Mengshuai Liu a Lin Liang c Tao Liang a Xiaoli Lin a Lei Shi a Fangxiao Wang a Jianmin Sun b a ⁎ a The Academy of Fundamental and Interdisciplinary Science, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150080, PR China The Academy of Fundamental and Interdisciplinary Science Harbin Institute of Technology Harbin 150080 PR China b State Key Laboratory of Urban Water Resource and Environment, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150080, PR China State Key Laboratory of Urban Water Resource and Environment Harbin Institute of Technology Harbin 150080 PR China c School of Life Science and Technology, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150080, PR China School of Life Science and Technology Harbin Institute of Technology Harbin 150080 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: State Key Laboratory of Urban Water Resource and Environment, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150080, PR China. Graphical abstract Catalytic coupling of carbon dioxide with epoxides to cyclic carbonates is an important reaction that has been receiving renewed interest. In this contribution, the binary catalysts of dicationic ionic liquids mediated metal halide were first evaluated in detail, together we provided an insight into the influence of various dications on catalytic activity to help the understanding and design of catalysts for efficient fixation of CO2 to epoxides. Among the catalysts, 1,1′-(hexane-1,6-diyl)-bis(3-methylimidazolium) dibromide (6a)/ZnI2 at molar ratio 1:2 showed the best catalytic activity with TOF of 328h−1 and 96% yield to propylene carbonate under solvent-free condition and 110°C, 1.5MPa for 2.0h. Also the catalytic system was effectively versatile to the cycloadditions of other less active epoxides with CO2. Compared with the reported monocationic ionic liquids, the dicationic ionic liquids exhibited the unique features of facile synthesis, easy separation, superior thermal stability and insensitivity to water and/or air, which make them good candidates for further developments and applications in sustainable processes concerned with CO2 fixation. Keywords Carbon dioxide Cycloaddition reaction Dicationic ionic liquids Cyclic carbonates 1 Introduction Currently, much attention is being focused on global warming and climate change mainly due to the large quantity of CO2 emission caused by the great consumption of fossil fuels [1,2]. The development of catalytic process for utilization of the waste CO2 in the production of commercially important chemicals under mild reaction conditions is one of the most promising strategies for carbon management and sustainable development, which simultaneously reduce atmospheric CO2 emissions and provide an alternative and renewable feedstock for the chemical industry [3]. Cyclic carbonates are valuable synthetic targets, which can be obtained through the coupling reaction between CO2 and epoxides (Scheme 1 ). Besides, this coupling approach with CO2 and epoxides benefits from eliminating toxic phosgene as reagent, and 100% atom economy makes it a highly desirable and green transformation. Additionally, cyclic carbonates have found wide applications as polar aprotic solvents, electrolytes for lithium-ion batteries, and as intermediates in the manufacture of fine chemicals [4–6]. Nevertheless, CO2 is an unreactive molecule and high energy barrier of the non-catalyzed cycloaddition associated with CO2 is necessary for the reaction to occur spontaneously [7,8]. So far, a plethora of catalytic systems for producing cyclic carbonates has been successfully developed in order to reduce the activation energy of the cycloaddition reaction, including metal oxides [9,10], alkali metal salts [11,12], metal–salen complexes [13,14], metal-organic framework (MOF) [15,16], microporous polymer [17], graphitic carbon nitride [18,19] and ionic liquids [20–24]. However, in many cases the developed catalysts are undesirable to industrial applications due to unsatisfactory activity, harsh reaction conditions, additional volatile organic solvents needed, inexhaustive separation of products from the catalyst, the sensitivity of catalyst to water and/or air. Hence, the design of novel, robust and active catalyst toward efficient fixation of CO2 under solvent-free and mild reaction conditions remains to be a great challenge [25]. Herein, a series of task-specific dicationic ionic liquids (ILs) composed of Br– anion and different cations were synthesized and well characterized. More importantly, dicationic ILs combined with Lewis acid cocatalyst showed remarkable activity towards the CO2 coupling reaction with high TOF values. Besides, the effects of reaction parameters such as various dications, reaction temperature, CO2 pressure and catalyst loadings on catalytic activities were investigated thoroughly. And a plausible reaction mechanism derived from the synergetic effects of dicationic ILs and metal halide was proposed based on the experimental results. Attractively, the dicationic ILs could be easily recycled by simple extraction, which avoided the complex distillation process and high energy consumption for the separation of products from the highly viscous monocationic ILs. Moreover, the dicationic ILs were very stable to water and/or air. The high efficiency, simple separation, superior thermal stability and insensitive to water and/or air make dicationic ILs in conjunction with metal halide appealing in the practical and effective CO2 conversions. 2 Experimental 2.1 General information Carbon dioxide with purity of 99.99% was purchased from Harbin Qinghua Industrial gases Co., Ltd. Propylene oxide (99%) was purchased from Beijing InnoChem Science & Technology Co., Ltd. N-methylimidazole, pyridine, 1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene, 1,2-dibromoethane, 1,4-dibromobutane, 1,6-dibromohexane, ZnCl2, ZnBr2 (CP), ZnI2 and other epoxides were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Co.. Other reagents and chemicals were all analytic grades unless otherwise stated and provided from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.. FT-IR spectra were measured on PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 FT-IR Spectrometer. 1H NMR spectra were detected on Bruker 400 spectrometer in D2O (4.79ppm) at ambient temperature. DSC–TGA experiments were performed on SDT Q600 (V20.9 Build 20) instrument under nitrogen atmosphere with the heating rate of 10°C/min from room temperature to 800°C. GC analyses were performed on Agilent GC-7890A equipped with capillary column (Agilent 19091J-413) using flame ionization detector. Melting points were measured on BÜCHI melting point B-540 apparatus. 2.2 Catalysts preparation and characterization ILs composed of bromine anion and different dications (Scheme 2 ) were prepared according to the published procedures [26]. The detailed synthesis procedures and DSC–TGA results are described in Supporting information. And these dicationic ILs showed much higher thermal stabilities up to 300°C than traditional monocationic ILs, which the thermal decomposition temperature ranged from 145°C to 185°C [27]. The typical FT-IR and 1H NMR results were as follows. [1,1′-(Butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(3-methylimidazolium)] dibromide (4a): Yield: 95%; White solid. Melting point: 110–111°C. 1H NMR (400MHz, D2O): δ =7.39 (d, J =11.5Hz, 4H), 4.18 (s, 4H), 3.82 (s, 6H), 1.83 (s, 4H). FT-IR: 3075, 2048, 1773, 1632, 1562, 1457, 1366, 1237, 1169, 855, 790, 648, 624cm−1. [1,1′-(Hexane-1,6-diyl)-bis(3-methylimidazolium)] dibromide (6a): Yield: 96%; White solid. Melting point: 150–151°C. 1H NMR (400MHz, D2O): δ =7.36 (d, J =14.8Hz, 4H), 4.10 (t, J =7.1Hz, 4H), 3.80 (s, 6H), 1.78 (s, 4H), 1.26 (s, 4H). FT-IR: 3082–2858, 1756, 1665, 1571, 1464–1299, 1184, 883, 793, 728, 621cm−1. [1,1′-(Butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(pyridinium)] dibromide (4c): Yield: 85%; White solid. Melting point: 233–234°C. 1H NMR (400MHz, D2O): δ =8.78 (d, J =5.7Hz, 4H), 8.49 (t, J =7.8Hz, 2H), 8.01 (t, J =6.6Hz, 4H), 4.61 (s, 4H), 2.13–1.99 (m, 4H). FT-IR: 3129–2866, 2399, 1956, 1631, 1579, 1488–1425, 1327, 1290, 1234, 1024–943, 784, 683cm−1. [1,1′-(Hexane-1,6-diyl)-bis(pyridinium)] dibromide (6c): Yield: 88%; White solid. Melting point: 235–236°C. 1H NMR (400MHz, D2O): δ =8.76 (d, J =5.2Hz, 4H), 8.47 (t, J =7.8Hz, 2H), 8.00 (d, J =6.2Hz, 4H), 4.53 (t, J =7.2Hz, 4H), 1.95 (s, 4H), 1.33 (s, 4H). FT-IR: 3054, 2934, 2855, 1630, 1484, 1166, 1145, 775, 671cm−1. [1,1′-(Ethane-1,2-diyl)-bis(1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene)] dibromide (2d): Yield: 91%; White solid. Melting point: 126–127°C. 1H NMR (400MHz, D2O): δ =3.66-3.43 (m, 9H), 3.29–3.23 (m, 5H), 2.54 (d, J =7.8Hz, 4H), 1.99–1.92 (m, 5H), 1.65–1.47 (m, 13H). FT-IR: 3192–2857, 2338, 1645, 1582, 1444, 1327, 1204, 1105, 980-833, 618cm−1. [1,1′-(Butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(1,8-Diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene)] dibromide (4d): Yield: 94%; White solid. Melting point: 279–280°C. 1H NMR (400MHz, D2O): δ =3.56–3.40 (m, 16H), 2.76 (d, J =7.4Hz, 4–H), 1.98 (s, 4H), 1.61 (d, J =18.6Hz, 16H). FT-IR: 3429, 2934, 2855, 1625, 1525, 1468, 1348, 1192, 1103, 1040, 978, 842, 733, 613cm−1. 2.3 Catalytic cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides The cycloaddition reactions were conducted in 50mL high pressure stainless-steel autoclave that equipped with magnetic stirring bar. For a typical catalytic reaction, the autoclave was charged with CO2 to evacuate air, then an appropriate amount of IL, Lewis acid cocatalyst and epoxide (34.5mmol) were added at room temperature. Then CO2 was introduced into the autoclave to a certain pressure when the autoclave was heated to the required temperature, and the autoclave was heated at that temperature for a designated period of time. After the reaction was completed, the autoclave was cooled to 0°C in an ice–water bath, and the remaining CO2 was released slowly. The product was extracted by toluene and analyzed on GC. And the catalysts were separated by centrifugalization, washed with toluene (3×5mL), dried under vacuum then reused directly for next run. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Influence of the dication structures Different dicationic ILs including methylimidazolium-, butylimidazolium-, pyridinium- and 1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene (DBU)-based were facilely synthesized. The effects of synthetic ILs combined with various zinc halide that had a strong Lewis acidity among the metal cations [28], on the coupling reaction of propylene oxide (PO) and CO2 are investigated in Table 1 . No product was detected in the absence of catalyst (entry 1) and ZnI2 alone (entry 2), and a low product yield of 18% was obtained over individual 4a (entry 3). However, the combination of 4a with ZnX2 (XCl, Br, I) exhibited pronounced catalytic activities for PC synthesis (entries 4–6), the yield of PC was markedly increased to 91% under mild, solvent-free conditions of 110°C and 1.5MPa CO2 for 2.0h, and TOF was high to 314h−1. Obviously, the notable catalytic activity of zinc halide with 4a was possibly originated from the synergistic effects of the acidic Zn sites cooperated with nucleophilic groups of X (XCl, Br, I) for epoxide ring-opening and tertiary nitrogen of imidazolium for CO2 activation [28]. Meantime, the activity of different anions in zinc halide decreased in the order of I– >Br– >Cl–, consistent with previous report [29]. As such, ZnI2 was chosen as the cocatalyst to combine with various dicationic ILs for the cycloaddition of CO2 and PO (entries 6–15). The dication structures of the ILs with the same 2Br−1 anions had strong effects on catalytic activity. The catalytic efficiencies improved with the increase of aliphatic bridge chain lengths for methylimidazolium- and pyridinium-based dication ILs (entries 6–8, 10–12 and entry 6 vs. entry 9), and the similar results have been reported by Sun et al. [24] and Kawanami et al. [30]. This phenomenon was explained that the stronger electron-donating ability of the aliphatic bridge chain weakened the electrostatic interaction between the ions and therefore led to a higher nucleophilicity of the bromine anion [31]. However, the steric hindrance mainly caused by IL cations also affected the activity to some extent. In the case of DBU-based dication (entries 13–15), the steric hindrance played the leading role in the catalytic activity and 2d with the shortest aliphatic chain bridge showed the best catalytic activity. With the same linkage chain length, the catalytic efficiency decreased in the order of 4b > 4a > 4d > 4c, this was understandable because stabilization of the ring-opened structure of epoxide was crucial for performing the cycloaddition reaction [22,32], and those cations which could help stabilizing the ring-opening intermediate would thus show higher activity. Herein, the delocalized cations showed better performances than Py cation (entries 9, 6 and 14 vs. 11). The alkyl imidazole cations (Mim or Bim) showed better activity than DBU cation (entries 9 and 6 vs. 14), as the C(2)–H in Mim (or Bim) cation could further stabilize the produced intermediate through hydrogen bonds formation with the epoxide, which has been demonstrated by theoretical studies [33]. Thus, 6a with ZnI2 displayed the most efficient activity for further investigation on the coupling reaction. Although the catalytic efficiency of the dicationic IL/ZnI2 was almost the same to the combination with monocationic IL, such as [Bmim]Br/ZnI2 (entry 16), [Bpy]Br/ZnI2 (entry 17), [BDBU]Br/ZnI2 (entry 18) and n-Bu4NBr/ZnI2 (entry 19), the easy-to-handle separation process as well as moisture-stable feature was tempting compared with the complex and high energy-consumption distillation process together with moisture-sensitivity for the monocation IL catalysts. In comparision with other reported dicationic/or Zn-containing ILs (Table 2 ), dicationic IL/ZnI2 catalytic system exhibited the unique advantages, such as high TOF values (entry 1 vs. 2–5, 8 and 9), mild reaction conditions (entry 1 vs. 6–9), features of facile synthesis (entry 1 vs. 2–4, 6–9) and easy handling as solid catalyst (entry 1 vs. 2–4, 6 and 7). 3.2 Effects of reaction parameters The influence of catalyst loadings on the CO2 coupling reaction over 6a/ZnI2 is shown in Table 3 . The catalytic activity strongly depended on the ratio of the two components in the binary system. When the molar amount of IL 6a was fixed at 0.025mmol and ZnI2 amount was varied from 0.025 to 0.100mmol, the PC yield increased from 35% to 74% (entries 1–4), whereas further improvement of ZnI2 to 0.125mmol, the PC yield increased slightly (entry 5). At 0.100mmol ZnI2 (0.29mol% of PO), the amounts of 6a were varied from 0.025 to 0.075mmol (entries 4, 6, 7), PC yield could reach optimal 96% at 0.050mmol 6a (0.14mol% of PO), whereas further increase of 6a resulted in a slight decrease in the product yield (entry 7). This could be attributed to the reason that in this homogeneous catalytic process increasing the catalyst concentration would enhance the mass transfer resistance between the active site and reagent caused by the low dispersity of the excess catalyst [38]. To our delight, the selectivity to PC was not influenced by catalyst loadings. Thus, the optimum 6a/ZnI2 molar ratio was 1:2 at the catalyst loading of 0.43mol% PO. In addition, the stability and reusability of 6a/ZnI2 catalysts were also investigated. After each run, the solid catalysts were separated from reaction system by adding toluene, centrifuged, washed, dried and then reused for the next batch. It was noted that in the 4th reuse the 6a/ZnI2 catalysts still exhibited high PC yield and selectivity but at the expense of a little longer reaction time (entries 8–10) due to the washing loss of catalyst. Generally speaking, 6a/ZnI2 exhibited efficient and reusable catalyst system for the CO2 cycloaddition reaction. Subsequently, the effects of reaction temperature on the catalytic activity over 6a/ZnI2 were investigated, as shown in Fig. 1 . The temperature had a pronounced positive effect on the coupling reaction from 80°C to 110°C, correspondingly, the PC yield was enhanced from 60% to 96%. To our delight, the selectivity to PC (≥98%) was not affected by the temperature. These phenomena were attributed to the increased homogeneity of the catalyst system in the reaction mixture at elevated temperature, thereby furnishing more effective collisions of substrates with active catalysts. With the temperature further increase higher than 110°C, the PC yield improved slightly. Generally, a significant drawback associated with CO2 as reagent or reaction medium in organic synthesis is the potential dangers operated at high pressures [22]. The effects of CO2 pressure on the PC synthesis catalyzed by 6a/ZnI2 are investigated in Fig. 2 . The PC yield increased dramatically in the low-pressure of 0.5–1.0MPa, then CO2 pressure showed a moderate enhancement for PC yield during 1.0–1.5MPa. According to the previous literatures [24,28,30], the results were attributed to the phase behavior involving CO2-rich gas phase and PO-rich liquid phase in this homogeneous catalytic system. The initial increase of CO2 pressure resulted in the enhancement of CO2 concentration in the liquid phase, thus improving the PC yield. Whereas further increasing CO2 pressure beyond 1.5MPa, there led to almost unchanged yield. The phenomenon was possibly explained that higher pressure extracted more PO into the gas phase, causing the reduction of PO concentration in the vicinity of the catalysts in the liquid phase. Conclusively, 1.5MPa was the optimal CO2 pressure for PC synthesis. Additionally, the effects of reaction time on the PC synthesis were also evaluated under the conditions of 110°C and 1.5MPa CO2. As shown in Fig. 3 , the cycloaddition reaction proceeded rapidly and PC yield increased from 44% to 96% when the reaction duration was extended from 0.5h to 2.0h. Further prolonging the reaction time resulted in only a slight rise in PC yield. Again, the selectivity to PC stayed above 98% throughout. 3.3 Catalytic activity towards other epoxides To survey the scope of substrates, we investigated the chemical fixation of CO2 to different terminal epoxides of propylene oxide, 1,2-epoxybutane, epichlorohydrin and styrene oxide, as well as internal epoxide of cyclohexene oxide, which was generally regarded as a more difficult substrate for the cycloaddition reaction with CO2 (Table 4 ). All examined terminal epoxides were smoothly converted to the corresponding cyclic carbonates with high yields and excellent selectivities (entries 1–4). The activity decreased with the alkyl length of epoxide increasing (entry 1 vs. entry 2) and the excellent activity of epichlorohydrin (entry 3) could be explained by the electron-withdrawing effect of its substituent, which facilitated nucleophilic attack to open the epoxide ring [39]. In addition, with the increase of the steric hindrance from side chain substituent, the catalytic activity was impeded (entries 4 and 5). Especially for cyclohexene oxide, much longer reaction time was needed to complete the conversion due to the higher hindrance originated from the two rings, which obstructed the nucleophilic attack of Br− and caused the decrease of ring-opening rate. Thus, both steric and electronic effects played the important roles in the chemical coupling reaction of epoxides and CO2. 3.4 Possible reaction mechanism According to the experimental and theoretical evidences [23,33,40,41], a plausible mechanism catalyzed by 6a/ZnI2 is proposed in Scheme 3 . The epoxide was firstly activated by ZnI2, C(2)–H and electronic interaction with the imidazolium dication, the X anions (Br– and/or I–) of the catalysts as Lewis bases subsequently attacked on the less sterically hindered β-carbon atom of epoxide (Step 1) to make the epoxy ring open to give the oxy-anion intermediate (Step 2). Then the oxy-anion intermediate made the nucleophilic attack on CO2 species activated by tertiary nitrogen of imidazolium to produce the new alkyl carbonate compound (Step 3). By the subsequent intramolecular ring-closure (Step 4), the cyclic carbonate could be formed and the catalysts were regenerated. Thus it can be seen the synergetic roles played by dicationic IL 6a and ZnI2 made the reaction proceed effectively. 4 Conclusions A series of dicationic ionic liquids with Br– anion were facilely synthesized and efficiently catalyzed the fixation of CO2 to epoxides cooperated with metal halide under mild reaction conditions without additional solvent. In this case, the dual catalysts of 1,1′-(hexane-1,6-diyl)-bis(3-methylimidazolium)] dibromide (6a) coupled with ZnI2 exhibited the best catalytic activity due to the synergetic effects. Zinc and imidazolium dication as well as halogen anion (Br– and/or I–) facilitated the ring-opening of epoxides and the tertiary nitrogen of imidazolium dication simultaneously activated CO2. Compared with the reported monocationic ILs, the dicationic ILs catalysts were proved to be thermostable, water and/or air insensitive and easy-to-handle separation, which avoided the complex and high energy-consumption distillation process for the separation of monocation ILs. Moreover, the dicationic ILs catalysts could be reused at least four times without significant loss of activity. All the unique features make dicationic ILs good candidates for further developments and applications in sustainable processes concerned with CO2 fixation. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic coupling of carbon dioxide with epoxides to cyclic carbonates is an important reaction that has been receiving renewed interest. In this contribution, the binary catalysts of dicationic ionic liquids mediated metal halide were first evaluated in detail, together we provided an insight into the influence of various dications on catalytic activity to help the understanding and design of catalysts for efficient fixation of CO2 to epoxides. Among the catalysts, 1,1′-(hexane-1,6-diyl)-bis(3-methylimidazolium) dibromide (6a)/ZnI2 at molar ratio 1:2 showed the best catalytic activity with TOF of 328h−1 and 96% yield to propylene carbonate under solvent-free condition and 110°C, 1.5MPa for 2.0h. Also the catalytic system was effectively versatile to the cycloadditions of other less active epoxides with CO2. Compared with the reported monocationic ionic liquids, the dicationic ionic liquids exhibited the unique features of facile synthesis, easy separation, superior thermal stability and insensitivity to water and/or air, which make them good candidates for further developments and applications in sustainable processes concerned with CO2 fixation.

coredata.dc:title: Cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides catalyzed by dicationic ionic liquids mediated metal halide: Influence of the dication on catalytic activity
